title: First pictures from Love Actually 2 show a VERY grown up Sam
text:

The first pictures from the Love Actually 'sequel' set show little Sam looking VERY grown up, 14 years after he made audiences cry with his declaration of young love. 
Thomas Brodie-Sangster, who is back playing Liam Neeson's stepson in the second version of Richard Curtis' rom-com, could be seen wearing a green jacket while he filmed a scene with Liam. 
Emma Freud, the writer and wife of Richard Curtis, shared a snap of the pair deep in conversation on a bench in front of the Thames. Thomas as the young Sam opposite Liam Neeson in 2003 (Photo: Unknown) 
"So this just happened. rednosedayactually day 1 of filming. Might have cried a tiny bit," she admitted. 
It comes after the 2003 film was announced as getting a sequel for this year's Comedy Relief and Red Nose Day. Liam Neeson embraces Thomas Brodie Sangster (Photo: WENN.com) The two are back to play the lovable father-stepson duo (Photo: WENN.com) Richard Curtis is back writing the 10-minute sequel (Photo: WENN.com) Richard Curtis is back writing the 10-minute sequel (Photo: WENN.com) Thomas, who played Sam in the 2003 original, looks very different now (Photo: WENN.com) 
Red Nose Day Actually, which many of the original cast have signed up to, will be just 10-minutes long and is written by Curtis himself. 
The likes of Hugh Grant, Martine McCutcheon, Keira Knightley and, of couse, Liam Neeson, are returning for the reunion. 
Curtis' short sequel will see many of the 2003 rom-com's characters dealing with life in the present day, 14 years after the events of the original film took place. Read More The secret romance in Love Actually you'll have probably missed The film will make a return as part of Comedy Relief and Red Nose Day, under the title Red Nose Day Actually (Photo: Publicity Picture) 
Speaking about the return of one of his most beloved creations, the British director said: "Over the years I've enjoyed doing Red Nose Day specials on TV things I've worked on – Blackadder , The Vicar of Dibley and Mr Bean . 
"It seemed like a fun idea this year to do a special sketch based on one of my films, since Red Nose Day is now in both the UK and America. 
"I would never have dreamt of writing a sequel to Love Actually , but I thought it might be fun to do ten minutes to see what everyone is now up to." Read More Andrew Lincoln admits his Love Actually character was a 'stalker' in iconic scene 
And of the likes of Hugh and Keira returning in their roles as the Prime Minister and Juliette, Lucia Moniz (Aurelia), Thomas Brodie-Sangster (Sam), Olivia Olson (Joanna), Bill Nighy (Billy), Marcus Brigstocke (Mikey), and Rowan Atkinson (Rufus) have all signed up to reprise their roles as well. 
And clearly delighted to have so many of the original cast back on board to tell the next chapter of his Noughties rom-com, Richard said: 
"We've been delighted and grateful that so many of the cast are around and able to take part – and it'll certainly be a nostalgic moment getting back together and recreating their characters 14 years later. The sequel will see many of the 2003 rom-com's characters dealing with life in the present day 
"We hope to make something that'll be fun – very much in the spirit of the original film and of Red Nose Day – and which we hope will help bring lots of viewers and cash to the Red Nose Day shows." 
However, fans of the show will have to be content with re-watching the original till Spring, as the Love Actually sketch won't be broadcast as part of Red Nose Day 2017, March 24, on BBC One. 
The original film followed the lives of eight very different couples in London (and abroad), dealing with their love lives in various interconecting tales all set during a frantic Christmas month. Read More
